facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 53 of 1961 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 53 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated August 9, 1956 of Madras High Court in O.S. Appeal No. 64 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 9, 1956 of the Madras High Court in O.S. Appeal No. 64 of 1952.

facts.text: Dominion of India, owner of Madras and Southern Mahratta Railway, represented by General Manager, invited tenders for supply of jaggery to railway grain shops.

anchor.surface_text: The Dominion of India, as the owner of the Madras and Southern Mahratta Railway, represented by the General Manager of that railway, invited tenders for the supply of jaggery to the railway grain shops.

facts.text: Respondent submitted tender for supply of 14,000 imperial maunds of cane jaggery during February and March 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent submitted his tender for the supply of 14,000 imperial maunds of cane jaggery during the months of February and March 1948.

facts.text: Tender form contained note in paragraph 2 reserving right to cancel the contract at any stage without calling up outstandings on unexpired portion.

anchor.surface_text: The tender form companytained a numbere in paragraph 2 which was meant for the quantity required and the described dates of delivery. This numbere was This Administration reserves the right to cancel the companytract

facts.text: Deputy General Manager accepted tender by letter dated January 29, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy General Manager of the Railways, by his letter dated January 29, 1948, accepted this tender.

facts.text: Acceptance letter asked respondent to remit Rs. 7,900 for security and stated official order would be placed on receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The letter asked the respondent to remit a sum of Rs. 7,900/-for security and said that on receipt of the remittance, official order would be placed with the respondent.

facts.text: Deputy General Manager by letter dated February 16, 1948 reiterated acceptance subject to terms on reverse including delivery programme.

anchor.surface_text: In his letter dated February 16, 1948, the Deputy General Manager reiterated the acceptance of the tender subject to the respondents acceptance of the terms and companyditions printed on the reverse of that letter.

facts.text: Terms included delivery: 3,600 maunds on March 1, 1948; 3,500 on March 22; 3,500 on April 5; 3,500 on April 21.

anchor.surface_text: Among these terms, the terms of delivery stated Programme of delivery to be 3,600 maunds on March 1, 1948 3,500 maunds on March 22, 1948 3,500 on April 5, 1948 and 3,500 maunds on April 21, 1948.

facts.text: Delivery dates slightly changed by letter dated February 28, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The date for the delivery of the four installments were slightly changed by a subsequent letter dated February 28, 1948.

facts.text: Deputy General Manager by letter dated March 8, 1948 informed respondent that balance quantity against order dated February 16, 1948 be treated as cancelled and contract closed.

anchor.surface_text: By his letter dated March 8, 1948, the Deputy General Manager informed the respondent that the balance quantity of jaggery outstanding on date against the order dated February 16, 1948, be treated as cancelled and the companytract closed.

facts.text: Respondent protested cancellation but railway stood by stipulation.

anchor.surface_text: The protests of the respondent were of numberavail as the railway administration took its stand against the stipulation that the right to cancel the companytract at any stage was reserved to it.

facts.text: Respondent instituted suit against Union of India for damages from breach of contract.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, the respondent instituted the suit against the Union of India for recovering damages resulting from breach of companytract.

facts.text: Trial Court dismissed the suit holding railway could cancel contract without liability for damages.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court dismissed the suit holding that the railway administration companyld cancel the companytract without giving any reason whenever it liked, without making itself liable to pay any damages.

facts.text: Madras High Court held cancellation clause void and remanded suit for decision on damages.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the clause reserving the right in the appellant to cancel the companytract was void and in view of the trial Court having number decided the issue about damages, remanded the suit for disposal after dealing with that matter.

facts.text: Union of India filed appeal after obtaining special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decree that the Union of India has filed this appeal after obtain- ing special leave.

facts.text: Tender paragraph 2 specified quantity 14,000 maunds for December 1947 and January 1948, equal lots from 10th Dec to 31st Jan.

anchor.surface_text: Quantity required and described dates of delivery.-14,000 imperial maunds of cane jaggery are required for the months of Decem- ber 1947 and January 1948 and should be deli- vered in equal lots of 1,750 imperial maunds each companymencing from 10th December 1947 and companypleted on 31st January 1948.

facts.text: Appellant contended contract was for quantity required up to maximum 14,000 maunds.

anchor.surface_text: The companytentions raised for the appellant are two. One is that on a proper companystruction of the terms of the companytract, the appellant had agreed to but only such quantity of jaggery as it might require, up to a maximum of 14,000 maunds

facts.text: Appellant contended respondent agreed to cancellation clause allowing termination at any stage.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore there was numberenforceable obligation to purchase the entire quantity. The other companytention is that the respondent had expressly agreed to the impugned clause and that therefore the appellant was at liberty to terminate the companytract

facts.text: Respondent contended contract was for definite 14,000 maunds on specified dates, cancellation only for good reason.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it is companytended for the respondent that the companytract was a companyplete companytract of the supply of a definite quantity of jaggery viz., 14,000 maunds, on the dates mentioned in the order dated February 16, 1948

facts.text: Court held formal order dated February 16, 1948 created binding contract for specified quantities and dates.

anchor.surface_text: Once the order is placed for such supply on such dates., that order amounts to a binding companytract making it incumbent on the respondent to supply jaggery in accordance with the terms of the order and also making it incumbent on the Deputy General Manager to accept the jaggery delivered in pursuance of that order.

facts.text: Cancellation clause applied only to supplies before formal order was placed.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the companydition mentioned in the numbere to para 2 of the tender or in the letter dated February 16, 1948, refers to a right in the appellant to cancel the agreement for such supply of jaggery about which numberformal order had been placed by the Deputy General Manager with the respondent.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 9, 1956 of the Madras High Court
It is against this decree that the Union of India has filed this appeal after obtaining special leave.

concepts.interpretation: Proper construction determines if contract is for definite quantity or up to maximum; clause applies only to pre-formal order supplies.

concepts.unlisted_description: Interpretation of contract terms to ascertain true nature, distinguishing between agreement and binding obligations.

concepts.interpretation: Acceptance of tender for supply up to maximum quantity creates standing offer, revocable until formal order for definite quantity and date, which then forms binding contract.
concepts.unlisted_description: Tender offering supply up to a maximum is standing offer; specific requisition creates separate binding contract.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy General Manager of the Railways, by his letter dated January 29, 1948, accepted this tender.

concepts.interpretation: Acceptance of tender constitutes agreement but not full legal contract without specified delivery dates and formal order.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: paragraphs 8 and 9 of the tender requiring a deposit of security and the placing of the formal order. The other case illustrated by Cheshire and Fifoo

concepts.unlisted_description: Principles governing when tender acceptance forms binding contract vs mere agreement.

anchor.surface_text: and that the stipulation relied on was repugnant to the contract and, even if valid, the appellant could rescind the contract only for good and reasonable ground and not arbitrarily.

concepts.interpretation: A clause reserving arbitrary right to cancel may be void if repugnant to main contract terms; not decided as clause interpreted narrowly.
concepts.unlisted_description: Contract clause void if it destroys or contradicts the essence of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent had expressly agreed to the impugned clause and that therefore the appellant was at liberty to terminate the contract at any stage of the duration of the contract with respect to the outstanding obligations under it.

concepts.interpretation: Cancellation clause provides for discharge or determination but limited to un-ordered supplies.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for termination or cancellation of contract at any stage without liability for unexpired portions.

anchor.surface_text: Once the order is placed for such supply on such dates., that order amounts to a binding contract making it incumbent on the respondent to supply jaggery in accordance with the terms of the order

concepts.interpretation: Formal order specifying quantity and delivery dates creates enforceable binding contract obliging both parties.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ove order, i.e., the order dated February 16, 1948, is treated as cancelled and the companytract closed. This letter itself draws a dis- tinction betw

concepts.unlisted_description: Enforceable legal contract arising from specific order under tender agreement.

issues.text: On a proper construction of the terms of the contract, whether the appellant had agreed to buy only such quantity of jaggery as it might require, up to a maximum of 14,000 maunds and therefore there was no enforceable obligation to purchase the entire quantity.

anchor.surface_text: One is that on a proper construction of the terms of the contract, the appellant had agreed to buy only such quantity of jaggery as it might require, up to a maximum of 14,000 maunds

issues.text: Whether the respondent had expressly agreed to the impugned clause such that the appellant was at liberty to terminate the contract at any stage of the duration of the contract with respect to the outstanding obligations under it, with the stipulation being valid and binding as a provision for discharge or determination.

anchor.surface_text: The other contention is that the respondent had expressly agreed to the impugned clause and that therefore the appellant was at liberty to terminate the contract at any stage of the duration of the contract with respect to the outstanding obligations under it.

issues.text: Whether the contract was a complete contract for the supply of a definite quantity of jaggery viz., 14,000 maunds on the specified dates, and whether the stipulation relied on was repugnant to the contract and, even if valid, allowed rescission only for good and reasonable ground and not arbitrarily.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it is contended for the respondent that the contract was a complete contract for the supply of a definite quantity of jaggery viz., 14,000 maunds, on the dates mentioned in the order dated February 16, 1948, to start with, and ultimately on the dates mentioned in the subsequent letter dated February 28,

issues.text: What is the true nature of the contract between the parties, specifically whether it constitutes a binding contract for a definite quantity or a standing offer requiring formal orders to create binding obligations.

anchor.surface_text: To decide the contentions raised it is necessary to construe the true nature of the contract between the parties which has given rise to these proceedings.

issues.text: Whether the cancellation clause applies to supplies for which a formal order specifying quantity and delivery dates has been placed, or only to un-ordered outstanding supplies.

anchor.surface_text: Once the order is placed for such supply on such dates., that order amounts to a binding contract making it incumbent on the respondent to supply jaggery in accordance with the terms of the order

arguments.claim: On a proper construction of the terms of the contract, the appellant had agreed to buy only such quantity of jaggery as it might require, up to a maximum of 14,000 maunds and therefore there was no enforceable obligation to purchase the entire quantity.

anchor.surface_text: The contentions raised for the appellant are two. One is that on a proper construction of the terms of the contract, the appellant had agreed to buy only such quantity of jaggery as it might require, up to a maximum of 14,000 maunds and therefore there was no enforceable obligation to purchase the entire quantity.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d the respondent about the cancellation of the companytract. The letter states that the balance quantity of jaggery outstanding on date against the ab

arguments.court_reasoning: Once the order is placed for such supply on such dates, that order amounts to a binding contract making it incumbent on the respondent to supply jaggery in accordance with the terms of the order and also making it incumbent on the Deputy General Manager to accept the jaggery delivered in pursuance of that order.

arguments.claim: The respondent had expressly agreed to the impugned clause and that therefore the appellant was at liberty to terminate the contract at any stage of the duration of the contract with respect to the outstanding obligations under it. The stipulation is valid and binding on the parties and it amounted to a provision in the contract itself for its discharge or determination.

anchor.surface_text: The other contention is that the respondent had expressly agreed to the impugned clause and that therefore the appellant was at liberty to terminate the contract at any stage of the duration of the contract with respect to the outstanding obligations under it.

arguments.court_reasoning: In view of the construction we have placed on the contract between the parties it is not necessary to decide the other contention urged for the appellant that the stipulation in the note amounted to a term in the contract itself for the discharge of the contract and therefore was valid.

arguments.claim: The contract was a complete contract for the supply of a definite quantity of jaggery viz., 14,000 maunds, on the dates mentioned in the order dated February 16, 1948, and that the stipulation relied on was repugnant to the contract and, even if valid, the appellant could rescind the contract only for good and reasonable ground and not arbitrarily.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it is contended for the respondent that the contract was a complete contract of the supply of a definite quantity of jaggery viz., 14,000 maunds, on the dates mentioned in the order dated February 16, 1948, to start with, and ultimately on the dates mentioned in the subsequent letter dated February 28,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d the respondent about the cancellation of the companytract. The letter states that the balance quantity of jaggery outstanding on date against the ab

arguments.court_reasoning: Formal order creates binding contract for definite quantity and dates; clause not repugnant as it applies only pre-order.

arguments.claim: The railway administration could cancel the contract without giving any reason whenever it liked, without making itself liable to pay any damages.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court dismissed the suit holding that the railway administration could cancel the contract without giving any reason whenever it liked, without making itself liable to pay any damages.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: it may require articles of a specified description up to a maximum amount, as, for instance, where it invites tenders for the supply during the compa

arguments.court_reasoning: Condition refers only to cancellation before formal order; does not apply to ordered supplies which form binding contract.

arguments.claim: The clause reserving the right in the appellant to cancel the contract was void.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the clause reserving the right in the appellant to cancel the contract was void and in view of the trial Court having not decided the issue about damages, remanded the suit for disposal after dealing with that matter.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: it may require articles of a specified description up to a maximum amount, as, for instance, where it invites tenders for the supply during the compa

arguments.court_reasoning: Clause valid but limited to supplies without formal order; formal orders create binding contracts not subject to arbitrary cancellation.

arguments.claim: The acceptance of the tender did not amount to the placing of the order for any definite quantity of jaggery on a definite date; only period mentioned, so agreement but not legal contract.

anchor.surface_text: The acceptance of the tender did not amount to the placing of the order for any definite quantity of jaggery on a definite date. Paragraph 9 of the tender referred to the placing of a formal order for the supply of jaggery, after the respondent had not only made a security deposit

arguments.claim: The note in paragraph 2 refers to cancelling the agreement at any stage without calling up outstandings on unexpired portion, meaning without ordering supplies for remaining period.

anchor.surface_text: So construed, the note in paragraph 2 of the tender would refer to cancel this agreement, loosely called a contract, at any stage during the tenure of that agreement without calling up the outstandings on the unexpired portion of the contract.

arguments.claim: Paragraph 13 distinguishes outstandings on the contract from supplies due under official order; cancellation under para 13(b) only for balance agreed but not yet supplied.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 13 dealing with penalties draws a distinction between outstandings on the contract and the purchase of the goods to the extent not supplied by the respondent.

arguments.claim: The letter dated February 16, 1948 places a definite formal order for entire 14,000 maunds in installments on specific dates, creating binding contract not subject to the cancellation note.

anchor.surface_text: Once the order is placed for such supply on such dates, that order amounts to a binding contract making it incumbent on the respondent to supply jaggery in accordance with the terms of the order and also making it incumbent on the Deputy General Manager to accept the jaggery delivered in pursuance of that order.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani: arrangement sets terms but contract arises only on order placement and acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: We may refer to what was said by this Court in Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram, in connection with an arrangement arrived at between the Central Government and a firm of bidi manufacturers, Moolji Sickka Company.

arguments.claim: Textbook Cheshire & Fifoot: acceptance of tender for maximum quantity creates standing offer, not binding contract until specific requisition.

anchor.surface_text: Reference may also be made to what is said in Law of Contract, by Cheshire Fifoot 5th Edition at p. 36. There is no doubt, of course, that the tender is an offer.

arguments.claim: The contract is of the second type: standing offer revocable until formal order for definite quantity creates separate binding contract.
The note reserving right to cancel is consistent with standing offer nature; applies only to supplies without orders placed.
The cancellation letter of March 8 distinguishes between order and contract; cancels balance against order but court holds invalid for ordered supplies.

anchor.surface_text: The letter states that the balance quantity of jaggery outstanding on date against the above order, i.e., the order dated February 16, 1948, is treated as cancelled and the contract closed.

holdings.text: Once the order is placed for such supply on such dates, that order amounts to a binding contract making it incumbent on the respondent to supply jaggery in accordance with the terms of the order and also making it incumbent on the Deputy General Manager to accept the jaggery delivered in pursuance of that order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Formal order under para 9 after security deposit specifies quantity and dates, transforming standing agreement into enforceable contract; distinguished from mere tender acceptance without specifics.

holdings.text: We are therefore of the view that the condition mentioned in the note to para 2 of the tender or in the letter dated February 16, 1948, refers to a right in the appellant to cancel the agreement for such supply of jaggery about which no formal order had been placed by the Deputy General Manager with the respondent and does not apply to such supplies of jaggery about which a formal order had been placed specifying definite amount of jaggery to be supplied and the definite date or definite short period for its actual delivery.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Note's language ('outstandings on unexpired portion') interpreted via para 13 distinction, cancellation letter phrasing, and consistency with standing offer; applies only pre-order.

holdings.text: We construe the contract between the parties in the instant case to be of the second type.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Matches Cheshire & Fifoot's second case of maximum quantity tender as revocable standing offer until specific requisition; analogous to Chatturbhuj precedent on orders creating contracts.

holdings.text: So far, the offer of a supply of a definite quantity of jaggery during a specified period at a certain rate and the acceptance of the offer would constitute an agreement, but would fall short of amounting to a legal contract inasmuch as the date of delivery of the jaggery was not specified.

anchor.surface_text: So far, the offer of a supply of a definite quantity of jaggery during a specified period at a certain rate and the acceptance of the offer would constitute an agreement, but would fall short of amounting to a legal contract inasmuch as the date of delivery of the jaggery was not specified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tender para 2 specifies period only, not dates; para 9 requires formal order post-security for binding supply obligation.

precedents.citation: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram  1

anchor.surface_text: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram  1 , in connection with an arrangement arrived at between the Central Government and a firm of bidi manufacturers, Moolji Sickka Company. The arrangement under which the firm was to sell and the Government was to buy from the firm from time to time two brands of bidis manufactured by it. The contention raised before the Court was that this arrangement amounted to a contract for the supply of goods within the meaning of that section.

precedents.case_name: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram
precedents.cited_proposition: Acceptance of tender or arrangement sets out terms for doing business if and when orders are placed, but does not create a binding contract until an order is placed and accepted
precedents.cited_holding: But except for this the letters merely set out the terms on which the parties were ready to do business with each other if and when orders were placed and executed. As soon as an order was placed and accepted a contract arose. It is true this contract would be governed by the term set out in the letters but until an order was placed and accepted there was no contract.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the condition mentioned in the note to para 2 of the tender or in the letter dated February 16, 1948, refers to a right in the appellant to cancel the agreement for such supply of jaggery about which no formal order had been placed by the Deputy General Manager with the respondent.

outcome.relief_summary: Cancellation clause does not apply to formal orders placed; order dated February 16, 1948 creates binding contract obliging acceptance of supply
directions: Suit to proceed for assessment of damages as per High Court remand
